qas.question: What other language has a telicity contrast?
Aside from the accusative, where can the direct object of the verb be found?
What is the accusative used for?
What language does not have a telicity contrast?
Where can the direct object of the noun be found?
What is an example of a partial object?
What does a transitive noun create?

context: The direct object of the verb appears either in the accusative (for <a2_0><b5_0>total objects<b5_0/><a2_0/>) or in the <a1_0>partitive<a1_0/> (for partial objects). The accusative coincides with the genitive in the singular and with nominative in the plural. Accusative vs. <b4_0>partitive<b4_0/> case opposition of the object used with transitive verbs creates a <b7_0>telicity contrast<b7_0/>, just as in <a0_0><b3_0>Finnish<b3_0/><a0_0/>. This is a rough equivalent of the perfective vs. <b6_0>imperfective aspect opposition<b6_0/>.
